arm_group.description: Intervention Group:  3D Image Simulation + Standard Preoperative Evaluation Goal:  50 patients

Control Group: Patients will receive standard preoperative evaluation (2D imaging).
Goal:  50 patients

Patients who refuse the option of randomization but otherwise meet the inclusion and exclusion criteria will be offered participation in this study as part of a non-randomized cohort.
Goal:  50 Patients

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this trial is to evaluate the impact of incorporating three-dimensional
      (3D)imaging during preoperative consultation on patient reported outcomes in primary breast
      augmentation surgery.  3D imaging is an innovative technology that allows the surgeon to
      share with images how one could look after one's procedure. The patient's assessment will
      be collected using the Breast Q, an objective questionnaire that captures patient
      satisfaction with breast augmentation.

clinical_study.brief_title: 3D Breast Imaging for Cosmetic and Reconstructive Breast Surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Age 18 years or older

          -  Scheduled for elective breast augmentation cosmetic procedure.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Breast reconstruction for malignancy

          -  Cognitively unable to provide informed consent.

link.description: Click here for Washington University's study location.

facility.name: West County Plastic Surgeons of Washington University

investigator.last_name: Terence M Myckatyn, MD, FACS, FRCSC

clinical_study.official_title: 3D Breast Imaging for Cosmetic and Reconstructive Breast Surgery: Does 3D Improve Patient Reported Outcomes in Primary Breast Augmentation?

overall_official.last_name: Terence M Myckatyn, MD, FACS, FRCSC

primary_outcome.description: This module has 6 core items.  Three of these items are recently shown to statistically significantly improve in patients undergoing breast augmentation: 1) satisfaction with breasts, 2) psychological well-being, 3) sexual well-being.  The remaining core items: 4) satisfaction with care, 5) physical well-being, and 6) satisfaction with overall outcome will also be recorded. Estimated start of Breast Q complete data analysis is September 2015.

reference.citation: Tepper OM, Unger JG, Small KH, Feldman D, Kumar N, Choi M, Karp NS. Mammometrics: the standardization of aesthetic and reconstructive breast surgery. Plast Reconstr Surg. 2010 Jan;125(1):393-400. doi: 10.1097/PRS.0b013e3181c4966e.

Pusic AL, Klassen AF, Scott AM, Klok JA, Cordeiro PG, Cano SJ. Development of a new patient-reported outcome measure for breast surgery: the BREAST-Q. Plast Reconstr Surg. 2009 Aug;124(2):345-53. doi: 10.1097/PRS.0b013e3181aee807. PubMed PMID: 19644246.
